sp.p: Only look to the left. Eye him askance, that he mayn't perceive that we are looking at him.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: I see him. Troth, now's the time, in our mischief, for us to become supremely mischievous.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: 'Tis for you to begin.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Prithee, did you see him yourself? Aside. Don't spare your voice, so that he may hear.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. By my troth, I talked with his own self, at my ease, as long as I pleased, at my leisure, at my own discretion, just as I wished.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. Do you hear what she says?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PYRGOPOLINICES. I hear. How delighted she is because she had access to you.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. O happy woman that you are!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How I do seem to be loved!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You are deserving of it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. By my troth, 'tis passing strange what you say, that you had access to him and prevailed. They say that he is usually addressed, like a king, through letters or messengers.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. But, i' faith, 'twas with difficulty I had an opportunity of approaching and beseeching him.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PYRGOPOLINICES. How renowned you are among the fair

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. I shall submit, since Venus wills it so.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. By heavens! I return to Venus grateful thanks, and her I do beseech and entreat, that I may win him whom I love and whom I seek to win, and that to me he may prove gentle, and not make a difficulty about what I desire.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. I hope it may be so; although many ladies are seeking to win him for themselves, he disdains them and estranges himself from all but you alone.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Therefore this fear torments me, since he is so disdainful, lest his eyes, when he beholds me, should change his sentiments, and his own gracefulness should at once disdain my form.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. He will not do so; be of good heart.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. How she does slight herself!

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. I fear lest your account may have surpassed my looks.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. I've taken care of this, that you shall be fairer than his expectations.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Troth, if he shall refuse to take me as his wife, by heavens I'll embrace his knees and entreat him! If I shall be unable to prevail on him, in some way or other, I'll put myself to death. I'm quite sure that without him I cannot live.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. I see that I must prevent this woman's death. Shall I accost her?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: By no means; for you will be making yourself cheap if you lavish yourself away of your own accord. Let her come spontaneously, seek you, court you, strive to win you. Unless you wish to lose that glory which you have, please have a care what you do. For I know that this was never the lot of any mortal, except two persons, yourself and Phaon of LesbosPhaon of Lesbos: Sappho, the poetess, was enamoured of Phaon the Lesbian. When he deserted her, she threw herself from the Leucadian promontory or Lover's Leap, which was supposed to provide a cure for unrequited love. Her death was the consequence. See her Epistle to Phaon, the twenty-first of the Heroides of Ovid., to be loved so desperately.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. I'll go in-doorsI'll go indoors: It must be remembered, that all this time they have pretended not to see Palaestrio or his master. Milphidippa cautioned her mistress only to take a side-glance at him (limis), after which they have, probably turned their backs.--or, my dear Milphidippa, do you call him out of doors.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. Aye; let's wait until some one comes out.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. I can't restrain myself from going il to him.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. The door's fastened. ACROT. aloud. I'll break it in then.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. You are not in your senses.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. If he has ever loved, or if he has wisdom equal to his beauty, whatever I may do through love, he will pardon me by reason of his compassionate feelings.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PYRGOPOLINICES. Prithee, do see, how distracted the poor thing is with love.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. 'Tis mutual in us.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Hush! Don't you let her hear.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. Why do you stand stupefied? Why don't you knock?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Because he is not within whom I want.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. How do you knowHow do you know: In Ritschel's edition, these words are attributed to Palaestrio. This is clearly a mistake, for Palaestrio has not yet joined in their conversation. He and his master are listening to what they say.?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. By my troth, I do know it easily; for my nose would scent him if he were within.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. She is a diviner. Because she is in love with me, Venus has made her prophesy.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. He is somewhere or other close at hand whom I do so long to behold. I'm sure I smell him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. Troth, now, she really sees better with her nose than with her eyes.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PYRGOPOLINICES. She is blind from love.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Prithee, do support me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. Why?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Lest I should fall.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. Why?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Because I cannot stand; my senses--my senses are sinking so by reason of my eyes.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. Heavens! you've seen the Captain.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. I have.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. I don't see him. Where is he?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. Troth, you would see him if you were in tove.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: aloud. I' faith, you don't love him more than I do myself, with your good leave.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PYRGOPOLINICES. No doubt all of the women, as soon as each has seen you, are in love with you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. I don't know whether you have heard it from me or not; I'm the grandson of Venus.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: aloud. My dear Milphidippa, prithee do approach and accost him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: to PALAESTRIO. How she does stand in awe of me!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PYRGOPOLINICES. She is coming towards us.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: advancing. I wish to speak with you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And we with you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I have brought my mistress out of the house, as you requested me.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: So I see.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Request her, then, to approach.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Since you have entreated it, I have prevailed upon my mind not to detest her just like other women.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I' faith she wouldn't be able to utter a word if she were to come near you; while she was looking at you, her eyes have in the meantime tied her tongue.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I see that this woman's disorder must be cured.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: See how terrified she is since she beheld you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Even armed men are the same; don't wonder at a woman being so. But what does she wish me to do?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: You to come to her house; she wishes to live and to pass her life with you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What!--I come home to her, when she is a married woman? Her husband is to be stood in fear of.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Why,--for your sake, she has turned her husband out of her house.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How? How could she do so?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: The house was her marriage-portion.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Was it so?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: It was so, on my word.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Bid her go home; I'll be there just now.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Take care, and don't keep her in expectation; don't torment her feelings.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Not I, indeed. Do you go then.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: We are going. ACROTELEUTIUM and MILPHIDIPPA go into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: But what do I see?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What do you see?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: See there, some one is coming, I know not who, but in a sailor's dress.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: He is surely wanting us, now; really, it is the shipmaster.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: He's come, I suppose, to fetch her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I fancy so.

div2.stage: Enter PLEUSICLES, at a distance, in a Sailor's dress.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: to himself. Did I not know that another man in other ways has done many a thing unbecomingly on account of love, I should be more ashamed by reason of love for me to be going in this garb. But since I have learned that many persons by reason of love have committed many actions, disgraceful and estranged from what is good, * * * * * for I pass by how Achilles sufferedAchilles suffered: This was when he withdrew from the warfare on being deprived of Briseis by Agamemnon, on which occasion Hector made great havoc among the Grecian forces. his comrades to be slain----But there's Palaestrio, he's standing with the Captain. My talk must now be changed for another kind. Woman is surely born of tardiness itself. For every other delay, which is a delay just as much, seems a less delay than that which is on account of a woman. I really think that this is done merely from habit. But I shall call for this Philocomasium. I'll knock at the door then. Hallo! is there any one here? Knocks at the CAPTAIN'S door.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Young man--what is it? What do you want? Why are you knocking?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I'm come to inquire for Philocomasium; I'm come from her mother. If she's for going, let her set off. She is delaying us all; we wish to weigh anchor.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Her things have been some time in readiness. Hearkye, Palaestrio, take some assistants with you to carry to the ship her golden trinkets, her furniture, apparel, all her precious things. All the articles are already packed up which I gave her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I'll go. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, do make haste.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: There shall be no delay. Pray, what is it that has been doneThat has been done: He asks "what has been done with" or "become of," his eye? On which Pleusicles tells him, by way of a quibble, that he has got his eye, alluding to the right one, while the Captain refers to the left, against which the "lectica" is placed. with your eye?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Troth, hut I have my eye. Points to the right one.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: But the left one I mean.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I'll tell you. On account of the sea, I use this eye less; but if I kept away from the seaFrom the sea: There is a pun here, which cannot be preserved in the translation. "Si abstinuissem a mare" "If I kept away from the sea," may also be read, "Si abstinuissem amare," "If I refrained from loving." The Captain understands him in the former sense, thinking that he means that he has got a disease in his eye, which may be increased by leading a seafaring life., I should use the one like the other. But they are detaining me too long.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: See, here they are coming out.

div2.stage: Enter PALAESTRIO and PHILOCOMASIUM from the CAPTAIN'S house.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PHILOCOMASIUM. Prithee, when will you this day make an end of your weeping?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: What can I do but weep? I am going away hence where I have spent my days most happily.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: See, there's the man that has come from your mother and sister pointing to PLEUSICLES.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I see him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Palaestrio, do you hear?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Aren't you ordering those presents to be brought out which I gave her?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Health to you, Philocomasium.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: And health to you.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Your mother and sister bade me give their love to you.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Heaven prosper them.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: They beg you to set out, so that, while the wind is fair, they may set sail. But if your mother's eyes had been well, she would have comeShe would have come: Thornton justly observes that this excuse for the pretended mother not making her appearance is fair enough, but there is no reason alleged why the sister should not come, except that we may suppose that she stays to nurse and comfort her sick parent. together with me.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I'll go; although I do it with regret-duty compels me.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: You act wisely.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: If she had not been passing her life with myself, this day she would have been a blockhead.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I am distracted at this, that I am estranged from such a man. For you are able to make any woman what-ever abound in wit; and because I was living with you, for that reason I was of a very lofty spirit. I see that I must lose that loftiness of mind. Pretends to cry.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Don't weep.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I can't help it when I look upon you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Be of good courage.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I know what pain it is to me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I really don't wonder now, Philocomasium, if you were here with happiness to yourself, when I, a servant--as I look at him, weep because we are parting pretends to cry, so much have his beauty, his manners, his valour, captivated your feelings.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, do let me embrace you before I depart?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By all means

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: embracing him. O my eyes! O my life!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do hold up the woman, I entreat you, lest she should fall. He takes hold of her, and she pretends to faint.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Because, after she had quitted you, she suddenly became faint, poor thing.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Run in and fetch some water.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I want no water; but I had rather you would keep at a distance. Prithee, don't you interfere till she comes to.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: observing PLEUSICLES, who is holding PHILOCOMASIUM in his arm. They have their heads too closely in contact between them; I don't like it; he is soldering his lipsHe is soldering his lips: "Ferruminat" is a strong expression here; it literally means to weld iron with iron. hammering it in a red-hot state to hers. What the plague are you about?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I was trying whether she was breathing or not.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: You ought to have applied your ear then.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: If you had rather, I'll let her go.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: No, I don't care; do you support her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: To my misery, I'm quite distracted.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Go and bring here from in-doors all the things that I have given her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And even now, household God, do I salute thee before I depart; my fellow-servants, both male and female, all farewell, and happy may you live; prithee, though absent, among yourselves bestow your blessings upon me as well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Come, Palaestrio, be of good courage.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Alas! alas! I cannot but weep since from you I must depart.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Bear it with patience.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: feigning to recover. Ha! how's this? What means it? Hail, O light!

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Are you recovered now?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, what person am I embracing? I'm undone. Am I myself?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: in a low voice. Fear not, my delight.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What means all this?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Just now she swooned away here. * * * * * * I fear and dread that this at last may take placeMay take place: Palaestrio cannot help exclaiming against the indiscreet conduct of the lovers. The Captain overhears him, and asks him what is the matter. He adroitly turns it off, by saying, "that if thus openly ---- the goods and furniture are carried through the city, he very much fears that his, master will be censured for his extreme prodigality." too openly.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What is that you say?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I fear that some one may turn it to your discredit, while all these things are being carried after us through the city.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I have given away my own property, and not theirs. I care but little for other people. Be off then, go with the blessing of the Gods.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: 'Tis for your sake I say it.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And now farewell!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And heartily farewell to you!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: to PLEUSICLES and PHILOCOMASIUM as they leave. Go you quickly on; I'll overtake you directly; I wish to speak a few words with my master. To PYRGOPOLINICES. Although you have ever deemed others more faithful to yourself than me, still do I owe you many thanks for all things; and if such were your feelings, I would rather be a slave to you by far than be the freedman of another.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Be of good courage.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Ah me! When it comes in my mind, how my manners must be changed, how womanish manners must be learnt, and the military ones forgotten!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Take care and be honest.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I can be so no longer; I have lost all inclinationLost all inclination: A pun is thought to be intended here on the word "lubidnem," but of so wretched a nature that it is not worth any further allusion to it..

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Go, follow them; don't linger.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Fare you right well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And heartily fare you well.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Prithee, do remember me; if perchance I should happen to be made free, I'll send the news to you; don't you forsake meDon't you forsake me: He hypocritically entreats his master not to desert him in need, should he be made free, and be thereby thrown entirely upon his own resources..

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: That is not my habit.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Consider every now and then how faithful I have been to you. If you do that, then at last you'll know who is honest towards you and who dishonest.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I know it; I have often found that true, as well before as to-day in especial.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you know it? Aye, and this day I'll make you hereafter say still more how true it is.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I can hardly refrain from bidding you to stay.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Take you care howTake you care how: There is considerable drollery in his anxiety lest his master should suddenly change his mind and refuse to let him go. His situation would, indeed, under such circumstances have proved an unfortunate one. you do that. They may say that you are a liar and not truthful, that you have no honor; they may say that no one of your slaves is trustworthy except my-self. If, indeed, I thought you could do it with honor, I should advise you. But it cannot be; take care how you do so.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Be off; I'll be content then, whatever happens.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Then, fare you well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: 'Twere better you should go with a good heart.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Still, once more, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Before this affair, I had always thought that he was a most rascally servant; still, I find that he is faithful to me. When I consider with myself, I have done unwisely in parting with him. I'll go hence at once now to my love here: the door, too, I perceive, makes a noise there.

div2.stage: Enter a BOY from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: to some one within. Don't you be advising me; I remember my duty; this moment I'll find him. Wherever on earth he may chance to be, I'll search him out; I'll not be sparing of my pains.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: 'Tis I he is looking for, I'll go and meet this boy.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: O, I'm looking for you; save you, dearest sir, one loaded by opportunity with her gifts, and whom before all others two Divinities do favour.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What two?

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: Mars and Venus.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: A sprightly boy.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: She entreats that you will go in; she wishes--she longs for you, and while expecting you, she's dying for you. Do succour one in love. Why do you stay? Why don't you go in?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Well, I'll go. Enters the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: There has he entangled himself at once in the toils. The snare is prepared: the old gentleman is standing at his postAt his post: He alludes to the attitude in which the old gentleman, Periplecomenus, is standing in-doors, ready to sally forth on the Captain the moment he is entrapped. to attack the letcher, who is so boastful of his good looks; who thinks that, whatever woman sees him, all are in love with him; whom all, both men and women, detest. Now I will on to the uproar; I hear a tumult within.

div2.stage: Enter PERIPLECOMENUS from his house, with CARIO and other SERVANTS, dragging PYRGOPOLINICES.Thornton here remarks, that "there cannot be a stranger proof of the absurdities into which the ancients were forced by a preservation of the unity of place than the present passage. The Captain is surprised in Periplecomenus's own house, carrying on an intrigue with the old gentleman's pretended wife, in consequence of which they proceed to frighten him with the cook's threatening to go to work upon him with his knife. Can anything be more unnatural or improbable than that for this purpose they should drag him out of the house and into the public street!

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Bring that fellow along. If he doesn't follow, drag him, lifted on highLifted on high: He means, "take him in your arms," or "hoist him on your shoulders.", out of doors. Make him to be between heaven and earth; cut him in pieces. They beat him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By my troth, I do entreat you, Periplecomenus.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: By my troth, you do entreat in vain. Take care, Cario, that that knife of yours is very sharp.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Why, it's already longing to rip up the stomach of this letcher. I'll make his entrails hang just as a bauble hangs from a baby's neck.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I'm a dead man.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Not yet; you say so too soon.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Shall I have at this fellow now?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Aye,--but first let him be thrashed with cudgels.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: True, right lustily.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why have you dared, you disgraceful fellow, to seduce another man's wife?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: So may the Gods bless me, she came to me of her own accord.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: It's a lie. Lay on. They are about to strike.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Stay, while I tell----

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why are you hesitating?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Will you not let me speak?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Speak, then.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I was entreated to come here.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: How did you dare? There's for you, take that. Strikes him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: O! O! I've had enough. Prithee, now.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Am I to begin cutting him up at once?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: As soon as you like. Stretch the fellow out, and spread out his pinionsSpread out his pinions: "Dispennite." He means, "stretch him out as you would spread out to their utmost length the wings of a bird." in opposite ways.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By heavens, prithee, do hear my words before he cuts me.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Speak before you're made of no sex.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I supposed that she was a widow; and so her maid, who was her go-between, informed me.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Now take an oath that you won't injure any person for this affair, because you have been beaten here today, or shall be beaten hereafter, if we let you go safe hence, you dear little grandson of VenusGrandson of Venus: This is an allusion to the Captains own boast in Act IV. s. 4, that he was the grandson of Venus..

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I swear by DioneBy Dione: Dione, according to Homer, was the name of the mother of Venus; but the name is much more frequently used, as in the present instance, to signify Venus herself. He appropriately swears by these guardian Deities of intrigue. The translation of l. 1416 is somewhat modified. and Mars that I will hurt no one because I have been beaten here this day; and I think that it was rightfully done; and if I don't go hence further injured, I am rightly punished for the offence.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: But what if you don't do so?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Then, may I always have my word not to be trustedNot to be trusted: "Intestabilis." A gross pun is here intended, and in l. 1420 as well. The word here signifies "forsworn," or "perjured," so infamous, that his testimony will never be received in a Court of justice.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Let him be beaten once more; after that I think he may be dismissed.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: May the Gods ever bless you, since you so kindly come as my advocate.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Give us a golden minaA golden mina: The golden "mina" was worth ten silver ones, or one thousand "drachmae," of about ninepence three-farthings each., then.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: That we may now let you go hence unmaimed, you little grandson of Venus; otherwise you shall not escape from here; don't you deceive yourself.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: It shall be given you.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: You're very wise. As for your tunic, and your scarfAnd your scarf: The "chlamys" was an outer garment worn among the Greeks and Oriental nations, somewhat resembling our scarfs. That worn by the Captain would probably be of great value, which of course would tempt the cupidity of his persecutors. The translation of l. 1426 is somewhat modified., and sword, don't at all hope for them; you shan't have them.

sp.speaker: A SERVANT.
sp.p: Shall I beat him again, or do you let him go?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I'm tamed by your cudgels. I do entreat you.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Loose him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I return you thanks.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: If I ever catch you here again, I'll insert a disqualifying clause.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Well: I make no objection.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p:
Let's go in, Cario. PERIPLECOMENUS, CARIO, and SERVANTS go into his house.
Enter SCLEDRUS and other SERVANTS of the CAPTAIN.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Here are some of my servants, I see. Tell me, is Philocomasium off yet.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Aye, some time since.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: You would say thatYou would say that: Sceledrus, probably, only enters at this moment with the other servants of the Captain; the editions, in general, somewhat absurdly represent him as present from the beginning of the Fifth Act. still more if you were to know what I know, for that fellow who had the wool before his eye was no sailor.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Who was he, then?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: A lover of Philocomasium's.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I do know: for after they had got out of the city gate, they didn't wait a moment before falling to kissing and embracing each other at once.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: O wretched fool that I am! I see that I have been gulled. That scoundrel of a fellow, Palaestrio, it was he that contrived this plot against me.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I think it was properly done. If it were so done to other letchers, there would be fewer letchers here; they would stand more in awe, and give their attention less to these pursuits.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Let's go into my house.

sp.speaker: AN ACTOR
sp.p: to the AUDIENCE. Give us your applause.
